issues.description: The template repository contains an Order class and an empty Meal.java, while the problem statement and the solution refer to a fully implemented Meal class. This creates a structural mismatch: students expect a ready-to-use Meal type (the problem explicitly lists 'Meal (Fully implemented)') but the template does not provide it and instead provides a different class name (Order). This will confuse students about which class to use and may lead them to implement or rename classes incorrectly. The Main examples in the template also reference Order in comments whereas the solution and problem use Meal.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide the Meal class in the template as described in the problem statement (implement the same Meal class the solution uses), or if Order was intended, update the problem statement and solution to refer to Order consistently. Specifically: (1) Implement Meal.java in the template with the constructor and getters shown in the solution, (2) remove or rename Order.java to Meal.java (and update any references in Main), and (3) ensure all examples and the UML/spec reference the same class name (Meal) so students are not confused about which type to use.

issues.description: The problem statement and solution refer to a Meal class (the UML and description explicitly name 'Meal'), but the template repository provides an Order class with the same shape (name + ingredients) instead of Meal. This mismatch (Meal vs Order) is likely to confuse students: the problem says a Meal class is available/expected, but the starter code forces them to either (a) notice and rename Order to Meal or (b) implement a new Meal class alongside Order. The conceptual entity (a meal definition carrying a name and ingredient list) is the same, but identifiers differ across artifacts, creating a mapping barrier.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template's Order class and its file to Meal (class Meal in Meal.java) and update any references (e.g., Main and comments) accordingly so the template, problem statement, and solution use the same identifier for the same concept. Alternatively, update the problem statement to accept 'Order' as the intended class name, but the cleaner fix is to make the template use 'Meal' to match the specification.
